bibl.title: The Pedroso Palace, by Lydia Cabrera, [19--]

div1.p: Cabrera writes about the history of the Pedroso Palace in Havana, Cuba.

div1.head: The Pedroso Palace, by Lydia Cabrera, [19--]
div1.p:
Among the best known of the historic monuments of Havana is cited
the old and manorial palace of the Pedroso family, one of the oldest and
and most illustrious Cuban lineage, closely united, by the position which
during the entire colonial period, was occupied by its members, to the
history and society of the City of Havana.

It was constructed in 1770 by Don Matheo de Pedroso y Florencia,
Ordinary Mayor in 1755, Heir, numerary and perpetual Alderman, who occupi
ed it with his numerous family, and later on by his widow, Doña Mariana
Barreto and his descendants. (See “Curioso Americano” 1907, Perez Beato,
genealogy of the Pedroso family.)

Rented by the illustrious patritian Don Juan Montalvo y O'Farrill
in 1840, the famous Countess of Merlin lived in it during her visit to
Havana, beeing the house at this time, the center of social activity, where
in honor of the Countess were celebrated magnificent feasts and concerts.
(See in Memoirs of the Countess a humorous description of one of these
concerts.)

The Royal Praetorian Audience was installed in 1843 in this Palace,
in which was celebrated, because of the taking of the oath of her Majesty
Queen Isabel II, one of the most splendid balls of the Colonial Period.
(See “La Habana Antigua y Moderna”, José Ma de la Torre, 1857.)

In 1850 General Concha also takes his oath in this historic house amid
great festivities.
The Praetorian Audience Chamber occupied it until 1870.

In 1878 and successively it was occupied by the Quarter of Public
Order.

The American Intervention installed in it the Correctional Court of
Police, its president being Mr. Pitcher, whose memory has been engraved
in the popular mind with the saying:
“Ten days, ten dollars,
Mr. Pitcher no traga bolas.”
thus signifying his spirit of justice and impartiality.

At the instauration of the Republic of Cuba, the palace was occupied
by the Precinct #1. The Secretary of Public Works was installed in it
from 1911 to 1925.

The works of reconstruccion and restauration of the palace was sub-
mitted to the Comission of National Archeology and agreeable to the
judgement of the historian Dr. Manuel Perez Beato, these beeing fulfilled
by Mr. Joaquin J. Weiss professor of Colonial Architecture of the Universi
ty of Havana.

The front measures 33 m. 30 cm., the widest facade of
Domestic Colonial Architecture in Havana.
